sen.j: 宿直（とのい）とは、律令法において宮中・官司あるいは貴人の警備を行うこと。
sen.e: Tonoi is to guard Imperial Palace, Kanshi (government officials) and the noble under the ancient Ritsuryo Code (criminal and civil laws.)
Tonoi is to guard the Imperial Palace, Kanshi (government officials) and the noblility under the ancient Ritsuryo Code (criminal and civil laws.)

sen.cmt: ピリオドの位置を変えました。

sen.j: 元来、職制律（在官応直不直条）においては昼の警備を「宿」、夜の警備を「直」と書いて「とのい」と読ませていたが、後世においては、夜の警備を「宿直」もしくは「殿居」と書いて「とのい」と読ませた。
sen.e: Originally under the Shikiseiritsu (penal code for government officials) the guarding activity during the day was expressed as "宿" and the night activity as "直" and the combination of "宿直" was read as "Tonoi," but later it only came to mean the guarding activity during the night, which was described "宿直" or "殿居" and both were read as Tonoi.

Originally under the Shikisei-ritsu (Office Penal Laws) (Zaikan Ochoku Fuchoku no jo (在官応直不直条, the article of guarding activities)) the guarding activity during the day was expressed as '宿' and the night activity as '直' and the combination of '宿直' was read as 'Tonoi,' but later it only came to mean the guarding activity during the night, which was described '宿直' or '殿居' and both were read as 'Tonoi.'
sen.cmt: 「在官応直不直条」については読み・意味共に確認できなかったため、推測される読みと漢字を補足しました。

sen.j: 公式令（百官宿直条）によれば、大納言以上及び八省卿を除く全ての官人に対して、その所属する官司に対して交代で宿直する義務を負った。
sen.e: According to Kushikiryo (Ritsuryo Code or Hyakkan-tonoijo,) all the Kanshi (government officials) except Dainagon or higher officials and ministers of eight departments were supposed to assume the obligation of Tonoi in alternate shits for the section to which they belonged.

According to Kushikiryo (Ritsuryo Code or Hyakkan-tonoijo,) all the Kanshi (government officials) except Dainagon or higher officials and ministers of eight departments were supposed to assume the obligation of Tonoi in alternate shifts for the section to which they belonged.

According to Kushiki-ryo (law on state documentary forms in the Yoro Code) (Hyakkan-tonoi no jo (百官宿直条, the article of Tonoi for all the officials)) all the Kanshi (government officials) except Dainagon (chief councilor of state) or higher officials and ministers of Hassho (eight ministries and agencies) were supposed to assume the obligation of Tonoi in alternate shifts for the section to which they belonged.
sen.cmt: リンク文字列が含まれていたので、原文・訳文共に修正しました。また「百官宿直条」は読み・意味共に確認できなかったため、推測される読みと漢字を補足しました。他、統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: 宿直の時間割は各官司の判官（太政官では少納言・弁官、八省では大丞・少丞、国司では掾がこれに相当する）が行い、毎日弁官に対してその名簿を提出した。
sen.e: The time table for Tonoi was made by the chief of each section, who were Shonagon and Benkan in Daijokan, Daijo and Shojo in eight governmental departments, Jo in local governments and was submitted to Benkan (one of the government officials) every day.
sen.cmt: 少納言、弁官、大丞、少丞、掾については適切な訳が見つからなかったので読み方のみで表記しました。
sen.e: The time table for Tonoi was made by the chief of each section, who were Shonagon and Benkan in Daijokan, Daijo and Shojo in eight governmental departments, Jo in local governments and was submitted to Benkan (one of the government officials) every day.

The time table for Tonoi was made by jo (inspector (third highest of the four administrative ranks of the ritsuryo period) of each section (which were corresponding Shonagon (lesser councilor of state) and Benkan (officials of the dajokan) in Daijokan (Grand Council of State), Taijo (Senior Secretary) and Shojo (Junior Secretary) in Hassho (eight ministries and agencies), and jo (provincial governor) in local governments) and was submitted to Benkan every day.

sen.j: また、これとは別に職務の一環として兵衛・内舎人は宮中を、大舎人・東宮舎人・中宮舎人は、それぞれ天皇・東宮・中宮を警備するために交代で宿直した。
sen.e: Besides the time table, as a part of their duties Hyoe and Udoneri guarded Imperial Palace, and O-doneri, Togu-toneri and Chugu-toneri guarded Emperor, Togu (Crown Prince's Palace) and Chu-gu (Empress's Palace) respevtively in alternate shifts.
sen.cmt: 兵衛・内舎人、大舎人、東宮舎人、中宮舎人は適切な役が見つからなかったので読み方のみを表記しました。
sen.e: Besides the time table, as a part of their duties, Hyoe and Udoneri guarded the Imperial Palace, and O-doneri, Togu-toneri and Chugu-toneri guarded the Emperor, Togu (Crown Prince's Palace) and Chu-gu (Empress's Palace) respectively in alternate shifts.

Besides above, as a part of their duties, Hyoe (palace guard) and udoneri (Ministerial equerry) guarded the Imperial Palace, and Otoneri (Royal Attendant), Togu Toneri (Officer of the Crown Prince's palace) and Chugu Toneri (Officer of the Household of the Empress) guarded the Emperor, Togu (Crown Prince's Palace) and Chugu (Empress's Palace) respectively in alternate shifts.

sen.j: 平安時代には近衛府が内裏及び大蔵・内蔵を夜間の警備を行った。
sen.e: During the Heian Period, Konoe-fu (the agency to guard the Palace) guarded at night the Imperial Palace and Okura (financial department) and Uchikua (tax agency.)

sen.j: 『延喜式』によれば、亥の刻・子の刻は左近衛府が、丑の刻・寅の刻は右近衛府が担当している。
sen.e: According to "Engishiki "(provisions to hold events and affairs in Imperial Palace), through I-no-koku to Ne-no-koku (through nine o'clock in the evening to one in the morning) Sakone-fu, and through Ushi-no-koku to Tora-no-koku Ukone-fu (through one o'clock to five in the morning) took the duty.

According to "Engishiki " (codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), Sakonefu (Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) took the duty from I-no-koku to Ne-no-koku (from nine o'clock in the evening to one in the morning), and Ukonefu (Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) did from Ushi-no-koku to Tora-no-koku (from one o'clock to five in the morning).
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを削除し、用語集に合わせ、表現を変えました。

sen.j: 近衛の官人は巡回の際に自らの姓名を叫びながら見回りを行ったが、これを宿奏（とのいもうし）と称した。
sen.e: Kanjin (government officials) in Konoe-fu patrolled crying out their own names, which was called Tonoi-moshi.

sen.j: また、律令の規定に関わらず大臣・大納言は中納言・蔵人頭・近衛大将とともに内裏内に置かれた宿直所（とのいどころ）・直盧（じきろ）に宿直して緊急事態に備えた。
sen.e: And in spite of the provisions of Ritsuryo Code, ministers and Dainagon (Major Couselor), along with Chunagon (Middle Counselor), Kurodo-no-to (a government official working as Emperor's secretary) Konoe-daisho (the chief of Konoe-fu) stayed at Tonoi-dokoro and Jikiro in Imperial Palace during the night in order to prepare for an emergency.

In spite of the provisions of the Ritsuryo Code, ministers and Dainagon (Major Counselor), along with Chunagon (Middle Counselor), Kurodo-no-to (a government official working as the Emperor's secretary) Konoe-daisho (the chief of Konoe-fu) stayed at Tonoi-dokoro and Jikiro in the Imperial Palace during the night in order to prepare for an emergency.

In spite of the provisions of the Ritsuryo Code, ministers and Dainagon, along with Chunagon, Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain) and Konoe no daisho (Major Captain of the Palace Guards), stayed at Tonoidokoro (Tonoi's station) and Jikiro (ministers and counselors' station for attendance) in the Imperial Palace during the night in order to prepare for an emergency.
